Next, we asked how Arabidopsis recognizes the invasion by Ab to activate the biosynthesis of ICAs and camalexin. The candidate mechanism critical for this process is the PRRs-dependent PAMP recognition machinery
28, 29 . When Arabidopsis recognizes PAMPs, at least some of the cognate PRRs, including FLS2 and EFR receptor-like kinases (RLKs), form complexes with coreceptors such as BAK1
19– 22 . Therefore, we decided to assess the possible involvement of BAK1 in the invasion-triggered accumulation of ICAs and camalexin. For this purpose, we used two mutant alleles of BAK1, bak1–4 and bak1–5; of these, bak1–4 is a BAK1 null allele
19 , and bak1–5 is a semi-dominant allele with a specific phenotype related to PAMP responsiveness
25 . Importantly, it was reported that bak1-5 is more severely impaired in elf18 and flg22 responses than the null mutant bak1-4
25 .
